articles.title: Jamaicans mobilize aid in aftermath of Melissa's wreckage
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: Residents help move food supplies to the Whitehouse community in Westmoreland, Jamaica, one of the areas most severely affected by the passage of Hurricane Melissa. The supplies will be distributed to the community center and distributed to Whitehouse residents.   .

articles.title: Jamaicans mobilize aid in aftermath of Melissa's wreckage
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa Ricardo Makyn passed through Jamaica. The Whitehouse community in Westmoreland was one of the most severely affected areas. Residents helped move food supplies at a community center before they were distributed to the Whitehouse area. The video is part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange.

articles.title: Popular Anacortes lecture series to kick off Nov. 14
articles.author: Nicholas Johnson
articles.summary: The Salish Sea and its wild inhabitants face a host of threats, from pollution and overfishing to habitat loss and invasive species, not to mention climate change. 'In conservation work, there's often quite a bit of doom and gloom,' said Bob Friel.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Deals Another Heavy Blow to Jamaica's Farmers and Fishers
articles.summary: At least 28 people were killed by Hurricane Melissa. The storm destroyed homes and public infrastructure in Jamaica. It will affect the livelihoods of tens of thousands of fishers and farmers. 80% of farmers are small-scale producers working on 2 hectares of land or less.

articles.title: New strategy to tackle climate change locally
articles.author: Ryan Bellingham
articles.summary: The North Central Catchment Management Authority is introducing a strategy that aims to prepare the region for climate change. The strategy is aimed at the catchment management authority and the people of the North Central catchment. It is called "Climate Change Preparedness Strategy".

articles.title: Tropics are quiet as we kick off November
articles.author: Katie Walls
articles.summary: Tropical system development is not expected during the next 7 days in the Atlantic basin. La Niña conditions are present and favored to persist through December 2025 through February 2026, with a transition to ENSO-neutral likely in January-March 2026.

articles.title: Restricted fire season begins for Hawke's Bay amid rising wildfire risk
articles.author: Jack Riddell
articles.summary: Hawke's Bay is moving into a restricted fire season from midday on Tuesday until further notice. A permit is required from Fire and Emergency New Zealand to light a fire in the open air. Warm weather is enveloping the region and restricts the fire season.

articles.title: With SNAP shutdown, Food Bank Finder helps Palm Beach County residents find meals
articles.author: Valentina Palm
articles.summary: Palm Beach County's government shutdown means tens of thousands of households might lose the aid they receive from a key federal food assistance program. About 160,000 Palm Beach County residents rely on SNAP to afford meals. The Trump administration will send partial payments to the tens of millions of Americans who receive SNAP, using a reserve account to cover 50% of eligible households' current allotments.

articles.title: Discover wintering birds of western Mount Desert Island with the Gilley Museum
articles.summary: Bird Chatter will begin indoors at Wendell Gilley Museum at 9 a.m. on Nov. 15 and last until approximately noon. Participants will car-caravan to a local hotspot or two, led by field ornithologist Seth Benz. The destination depends on bird activity in the area.

articles.title: Their houses are being swept into the sea. Why many Senegalese won't leave.
articles.author: The Christian Science Monitor
articles.summary: Rising sea levels are eroding Senegal's shorelines due to sea level rise.   Â££1.5 billion per year is being spent on dredging the shorelines.  £1.6 billion is spent on building up the shoreline.

articles.title: Their houses are being swept into the sea. Why many Senegalese won't leave.
articles.author: The Christian Science Monitor
articles.summary: As sea levels rise, coastal communities around the world face an existential choice: stay and fight, or retreat to safer ground? In Senegal, that's still an open question. The 466-mile coastline is the lifeblood of the country's economy, generating millions of jobs in fisheries, tourism, and horticulture, and providing homes to 50% of the population. The World Bank estimates that three-quarters of the coastline will be affected by erosion in the next 50 years.

articles.title: Australia has a severe tradie shortage
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: Build Skills Australia released a report last month. The building rate per new resident has plummeted despite the fact that the number of homes built over the last 20 years has been significantly higher than the previous 20 years. This is because Australia's population has grown at a faster rate thanks to record net overseas migration.

articles.title: Bill Gates is wrong to quiet-quit the climate fight — and we would be, too
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Bill Gates is giving ammunition to those fighting against climate change. The Microsoft founder has long led the charge to keep the planet from overheating, dedicating money and attention to the cause and helping make real change possible, but his heart no longer appears to be in it. In a note on his website titled 'Three tough truths about climate,' Gates suggests negotiators at this month's COP30 climate summit in Brazil should focus on improving lives.

articles.title: Jamaican farm workers in Norfolk County keep the faith in wake of Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Vincent Ball
articles.summary: More than 130 farm workers from Norfolk County gathered at the recreation hall at Schuyler Farms near Simcoe on Sunday to celebrate life in the wake of Hurricane Melissa. The service was two hours of respite after the worst hurricane in recent Jamaican history ravaged their homeland. Some of the workers are scheduled to head home to Jamaica in a couple of weeks while others will remain in Norfolk into December.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa leaves coffee-growing areas in Buey Arriba isolated and threatens the harvest in Granma
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa damaged the infrastructure of the coffee plantations in Buey Arriba, Granma province. The access routes to the mountainous areas have been destroyed, which complicates the harvesting and transportation of coffee to the collection centers. The Revolutionary Armed Forces (FAR) is mobilizing to collect the coffee. More than 3,600 cans of coffee have already been collected.

articles.title: October was warmer and drier than normal
articles.author: Paul Cowley
articles.summary: It was the driest October in 111 years of record keeping and the 48th warmest October since record keeping began in 1904. The average mean temperature was 5.1 C, compared with the historical mean of 3.9 C. A cold front blew in mid-month and produced a record-setting cold temperature of -12.7 C in Red Deer.

articles.title: Economist warns that financial insecurity exacerbates the tragedy of the victims of Hurricane Melissa in Cuba
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Pedro Monreal warns of the long-term consequences of Hurricane Melissa in Cuba. He argues that the most critical factor in the recovery of Caribbean countries after hurricanes is the level of poverty and access to preexisting financial resources. Monreal compares the situation in Cuba with that of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic after hurricanes María (2017) and David (2017). He also criticizes the Council of Ministers Agreement 10/247, which proposes supposed subsidies and soft loans for those affected.

articles.title: Kipnuk leaders reflect on what federal help could have done before the storm, and what can be done now
articles.author: Knba
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong devastated about a dozen villages in the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta in Western Alaska earlier this month. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency canceled a grant that would have helped Kipnuk to protect its infrastructure from flooding. The village is among 23 cities and tribal and environmental organizations that are challenging that decision in court.

articles.title: Matthew Wielicki: Pulls back the curtain on the massive climate grift
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: October was all about unmasking the hype. We dove into wildfire myths, debunked sinking island narratives, and pulled back the curtain on the massive climate grift that's draining trillions from taxpayers. Paid subscribers get the charts, plain-English breakdowns, exclusive deep dives, and the full archive.

articles.title: Is Bill Gates right? Call to put climate resilience before rising temperatures
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: There is too much effort devoted to climate change and not enough to helping humans adapt to the new climate, says Dr. Richard Branson. He is concerned that too much attention is devoted to the climate change, rather than to helping people adapt to a new climate.

articles.title: The Sun's magnetic field flipped—what happens next?
articles.author: Stars Insider
articles.summary: The Sun has flipped its magnetic field once again. This dramatic shift is a fundamental aspect of solar dynamics and signals the peak of solar activity. Scientists have been tracking this event with great interest, using advanced space observatories to study how the Sun's evolving magnetic field influences the solar system.

articles.title: Half in Melbourne, Half in Moresby
articles.author: Post-Courier
articles.summary: A donkey race in Australia stops Australia in its tracks for 3 minutes. Even Papua New Guinea suffers from the Melbourne Cup heatwave from the heatwave. subscribe to the Post Courier with K3.00/day or K5/day for access to all Post Courier articles.

articles.title: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by almost half in just two months. Scientists say it could happen again
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier on Antarctica's Eastern Peninsula experienced the fastest retreat recorded in modern history, losing nearly 50% of its mass in just two months. Satellite data and seismic instruments confirmed that the ice loss contributed directly to global sea level rise. There are concerns about the potential for larger Antarctic glaciers to experience similar rapid retreats.

articles.title: How will La Niña impact Wisconsin winter?
articles.author: --Ppa-Color-Scheme
articles.summary: La Niña is back, but it won't affect all of Wisconsin in the same way. La Niña influences the jet stream, directing colder air into the northern U.S. and the Pacific Ocean. Central and north-central Wisconsin could see sharper cold spells and bursts with a higher chance of snow this winter.

articles.title: October Recap: Exposing the Myths and Grifts in Climate Alarmism
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: October was all about unmasking the hype. Paid subscribers get the charts, plain-English breakdowns, exclusive deep dives, and the full archive. Long-time subscribers get a free autographed copy of Irrational Fear: Climate Change. For the next few days, get 20% off a one-year subscription.

articles.title: Wildfires burned nearly 6,000 square km in Ontario this year: ministry
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: 643 wildfires burned 597,654 hectares in Ontario between April and October this year. The 10-year average for Ontario is 712 fires and 2,100 square kilometres burned. Canada's 2025 wildfire season was the second-worst on record. Scientists say climate change has made Canada's fire seasons longer and more intense.

articles.title: UAH v6.1 Global Temperature Update for October, 2025: +0.53 deg. C
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: The Version 6.1 global average lower tropospheric temperature (LT) anomaly for October, 2025 was +0.53 deg. C departure from the 1991-2020 mean, unchanged from the September, 2025 value. The global area-averaged linear temperature trend (January 1979 through October 2025) remains at + 0.16 deg/ C/decade. The monthly anomalies for the four deep layers we monitor from satellites will be available in the next several days.

articles.title: Aussie farmers' $150/t urea carbon fear as Euro fert prices start to soar
articles.author: Jason Gregory
articles.summary: Farmers would face an estimated $300 million a year input price hike if a border tax on carbon-intensive imports were introduced in Australia, according to farm lobby group GrainGrowers, which is concerned about a possible increase in the input price.

articles.title: Category 6 is the new hurricane normal, scientists warn
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: human-caused climate change is making major difference.   Â.  yah. yah. yah, yuh. Yah, iyah, aye, iyah, yah,. iiyuh,

articles.title: 13 years after Sandy, NJ can't gamble on climate change. Sherrill for governor
articles.author: Raj Mukherji
articles.summary: It's the 13th anniversary of Hurricane Sandy. Sandy damaged or destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes, took 38 lives and caused tens of billions in economic losses in New Jersey. Sandy was the costliest disaster in the state's history. Instead of investing in the resilience of our communities, the federal government is gutting disaster relief programs and slashing clean energy investments. Utility bills are skyrocketing and AI data centers exacerbate the strain on the power grid. Half of New Jersey households say they struggle to afford their utility bills. Mikie Sherrill is running for governor. Her opponent would take us backward.

articles.title: Why climate change now threatens China's future
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Why climate change now threatens China's future, according to The Economist.    .      in The Economist  in which climate change is one of the main reasons for the current global warming trend.  In which the main reason is because of China's climate change.

articles.title: US Envoy Welcomes Iraq-Turkey Water Agreement as Milestone for Regional Cooperation
articles.author: Yousif Ismael
articles.summary: Mark Savaya congratulated both Iraq and Turkey on reaching a new agreement to address long-standing water management issues between the two neighboring countries. He stressed the importance of such cooperation for long-term regional stability. Iraq has long faced severe water shortages due to reduced river flows from neighboring countries, outdated infrastructure and the effects of climate change. Disputes over the management of shared rivers such as the Tigris and Euphrates have been a recurring issue between Baghdad and Ankara.

articles.title: Climate Crisis in Ghana: How rising temperatures are driving migration and environmental degradation
articles.summary: Ghana is on the frontlines of the climate crisis. Rising temperatures, prolonged droughts, and erratic rainfall are forcing farmers to abandon their lands in search of survival. Many migrate south to cities like Accra and Kumasi, but their movement is creating new challenges for both the environment and society.

articles.title: Jamaica rushes to prepare for peak tourism season as it digs out from Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: John Myers
articles.summary: People repair the roof of a resort in Montego Bay, Jamaica, Friday, Oct. 31, 2025, in the aftermath of Hurricane Melissa. The article is free to subscribe to and gift this article to friends and family for free, but you must have a subscription to receive it.

articles.title: Wildfires burned nearly 6,000 square kilometres in Ontario this year: ministry
articles.author: At P.M.
articles.summary: 643 wildfires burned 597,654 hectares in Ontario between April and October this year. The 10-year average for Ontario is 712 fires and about 2,100 square kilometres burned. Canada's 2025 wildfire season was the second-worst on record. Climate change has made Canada's fire seasons longer and more intense.

articles.title: Neglected solutions to our biggest problems
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: There are three great economic challenges of our time: climate change, the erosion of the middle class and poverty. The first is an existential threat to all of us, and we need new ideas to deal with it.    - Simon Tisdall.

articles.title: Antarctic glacier retreating at rate 10 times faster than previously measured: Study
articles.author: Julia Jacobo
articles.summary: Glaciologists recorded a five-mile retreat in two months on the Hektoria Glacier on the eastern Antarctic Peninsula. The retreat was 10 times faster than previously measured for a grounded glacier. Antarctica is subject of intense scrutiny by climate scientists due to its potential to contribute to sea level rise.

articles.title: The ground is swallowing homes in this Native village in Alaska. Residents have no choice but to move
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: Yup'ik people in south-western Alaska have long lived in the south-west Alaska. With global warming, life has gotten worse for the Yup’ik people, who live on the tundra and rely on fishing and hunting to survive.

articles.title: San Pablo de Yao, in Granma, remains isolated following the passage of Hurricane Melissa: No bridge, no electricity, and no communication
articles.author: Cibercuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The mountainous community of San Pablo de Yao, in the municipality of Buey Arriba in the province of Granma, remains isolated following the impacts of Hurricane Melissa. In Santiago de Cuba, communities such as Los Reynaldos and Brazo Escondido are also cut off after the collapse of bridges and the rise of rivers.

articles.title: ‘Salish Sea Wild' producer to kick off popular Anacortes lecture series Nov. 14
articles.author: Nicholas Johnson
articles.summary: The Salish Sea and its wild inhabitants face a host of threats, from pollution and overfishing to habitat loss and invasive species, not to mention climate change. 'In conservation work, there's often quite a bit of doom and gloom,' said Bob Friel.

articles.title: The climate action that matters is in the global south, argues an architect of the Paris agreement
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: The climate action that matters is in the global south, argues an architect of the Paris agreement, The Economist, in its article on the Paris Agreement. The Economist's article is based on an article by The Economist.    in its online edition, "The Economist".

articles.title: Still Sleepwalking Into The Elite's New World Order: Gaza As The Vision Of Our Technocratic And Transhuman Future
articles.author: Eurasia Review
articles.summary: The program of the Global Elite is advancing rapidly. Only a small number of well-researched analysts are paying the close attention necessary to understand the devastating significance of this phalanx of threats. For most people, fundamental questions in relation to who is driving primary events and how they are doing it are unanswered.

articles.title: Antarctic glacier saw the fastest retreat in modern history; it could spell trouble for sea levels, report finds
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier in Antarctica shrunk by nearly 50% in just two months. It's the fastest retreat recorded in modern history. If larger glaciers retreat at similar rates, it could have 'catastrophic implications for sea level rise'. Antarctica holds enough ice to raise global sea level by around 190 feet.

articles.title: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by almost half in just two months. Scientists say it could happen again
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier in Antarctica shrunk by nearly 50% in just two months. It's the fastest retreat recorded in modern history. If larger glaciers retreat at similar rates, it could have 'catastrophic implications for sea level rise'. Antarctica holds enough ice to raise global sea level by around 190 feet.

articles.title: Why a fast-shrinking Antarctic glacier has sparked fears of ‘catastrophic' sea level rise
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier in Antarctica shrunk by nearly 50% in two months. It's the fastest retreat recorded in modern history. If larger glaciers retreat at similar rates, it could have 'catastrophic implications for sea level rise'. Antarctica holds enough ice to raise global sea level by around 190 feet.

articles.title: Studies: Extreme Weather Fueled by Climate Change Is Adding to Bird Declines • The Revelator
articles.author: Rebecca Heisman
articles.summary: Bird populations across the globe have been decreasing sharply for decades. The total number of breeding birds in North America had dropped by almost 30% since 1970, and similarly sobering declines have been reported in Europe, the Neotropics, and other regions. Two studies published this year suggest that climate change is already playing a large role in bird declines.

articles.title: This Antarctic Glacier Just Broke An Unwanted Record – Fastest Retreat In Modern History
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: The Hektoria Glacier on the Antarctic Peninsula is disappearing at a rapid rate. It shrank by 8.2 km (5 miles) over November-December 2023. This is 10 times faster than any glacier ever observed. Global warming is at the root of this event. The authors think the calving caused local earthquakes recorded around this time.

articles.title: The ‘Climate Crisis' of 1695
articles.author: Ron Barmby
articles.summary: There is a widespread belief that between 1980 and 2020, we experienced a warming of the climate at a rate that is unprecedented in the last 2,000 years. However, sealed thermometer technology predates 1850 by approximately 200 years. The data compiled by the MET Office, the UK's national meteorological service, is a climate change record for central England dating back to 1695. The warming trend from 1695 to 1735, 2°C over four decades, was double that of 1980 to 2020, at 1°C.

articles.title: Daylight saving time ends, Georgia DNR warns about deer in road
articles.author: WSBTV.com News Staff
articles.summary: The fall deer breeding season occurs between October and late December. Male deer go into rut and start actively searching for mates. This behavior increases deer movement, often bringing them across roadways. Deer are unpredictable and can suddenly dart into the road with no warning. They are most active at dawn and dusk.

articles.title: Richest 1% drive 41% of global emissions, says climate inequality report
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: The richest 1% of people are responsible for 41% of global emissions linked to private capital ownership. The bottom 50% of the population could suffer 74% of income losses due to climate damage by 2050. Developed countries pay higher interest rates on green loans despite contributing less to global warming.

articles.title: Climate change inaction costs millions of lives each year, report warns
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The 2025 Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change reveals that climate inaction and continued dependence on fossil fuels is resulting in an immense human cost. Millions of lives are lost each year due to heat, air pollution, disease spread and worsening food insecurity. Many of the health impacts we see today wouldn't have occurred without human-driven climate change.

articles.title: Crooked Island farmer appeals for help after Hurricane Melissa devastates crops
articles.summary: Michael Carroll's banana and plantain crops on Crooked Island were destroyed by flooding and winds estimated at 120mph. Mr Carroll has farmed on the island for 14 years and estimated it would take 18 months for his crops to recover. Long Island MP Adrian Gibson said farmers in his constituency suffered similar damage and recovery efforts are now underway.

articles.title: Scientists predict a wetter, greener future for the Sahara Desert
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: UIC researchers predict that the Sahara Desert could see up to 75% more rain by the end of this century due to rising global temperatures. Using 40°C instead of 30°C, they predict the desert could get up to 40% more rainfall.

articles.title: Dry, cold conditions to persist; Northern Areas brace for rain, snow
articles.summary: A new westerly wave has entered the region, bringing the potential for light rain and snowfall in northern areas, particularly in Chitral, Dir, Malakand, Abbottabad, and Mansehra on November 3 and 4. Residents in these regions have been advised to prepare for colder temperatures and possible travel disruptions. Dry weather is expected to continue from November 3 to 8 in Punjab, with fog and smog likely to affect visibility and air quality. Balochistan will experience dry conditions throughout the week.

articles.title: North India's winter guestlist: The epic journey of the migratory birds
articles.author: Precious Rongmei
articles.summary: Every winter, millions of migratory birds travel thousands of kilometres to India to escape the freezing conditions of their northern breeding grounds in regions like Siberia, Central Asia, and Europe. India's mild winter climate and diverse ecosystems provide the ideal refuge for these travellers. Indian wetlands like Chilika Lake, Keoladeo National Park, Pong Dam, and Nal Sarovar play a vital role in sustaining these species during their migration cycles. Delhi Bird Atlas is a large-scale citizen science initiative aimed at systematically documenting the distribution and diversity of birds across the city.

articles.title: 2024 Bleaching Event Devastates Northern Great Barrier Reef
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In the journal Coral Reefs, Emslie, Ceccarelli and Logan report on the Great Barrier Reef during the bleaching event of 2024. The northern section of the GBR, often recognized for its biodiversity, faced overwhelming coral loss due to extreme heat. The research points to the urgent need for global climate action and conservation strategies.

articles.title: The purposeful misinterpretation of Bill Gate's climate message to world leaders
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Last week, Bill Gates said that world leaders are paying too little attention to reducing climate-altering pollution and too little to reducing human pollution. He added that this will not lead to humanity's demise, as he said last week at the COP-30 climate talks.

articles.title: Adapting to a warming planet: the next phase of climate survival
articles.summary: As extreme weather intensifies and sea levels rise, the world is entering a new phase: adaptation. The cost of adaptation is estimated to exceed $300 billion annually by 2030. Wealthy nations have pledged billions to help developing countries adapt. Without fair financing, rich nations harden themselves against climate impacts while poorer ones are left exposed.

articles.title: In Decade Since Paris Agreement, Climate Outlook Has Improved Dramatically
articles.author: Yale Environment 360
articles.summary: A new report finds that the world is headed for 2.8 degrees C of warming by the end of this century, far less than was forecast before the Paris Climate Agreement. However, countries remain far off track from the international target of 2 degrees C. Over the last 10 years, the cost of clean energy has dropped dramatically. The price of onshore wind has fallen 70%, while prices for solar and batteries have fallen by roughly 90%.

articles.title: Pakistan Red Crescent Society hosts Pre-COP30 Dialogue, calls for climate justice and support
articles.summary: Pakistan Red Crescent Society (PRCS) and German Red Cross organized a high level 'Pakistan Pre-COP30 National Dialogue 2025' here on Monday. The event gathered lawmakers, humanitarian leaders, climate experts, and youth to help shape Pakistan's unified stance ahead of COP30 in Brazil.

articles.title: Kenya's deadly landslides test the country's climate readiness
articles.author: Kwabena Adu Gyamfi
articles.summary: 26 people died in a landslide in Elgeyo Marakwet County, Kenya, due to heavy rains triggered by El Niño. The disaster highlights Kenya's vulnerability to climate change and the importance of long-term adaptation. Kenya has developed a National Climate Change Action Plan and established a Climate Change Council chaired by the president.

articles.title: 75% of Australians Share a Common Fear That Could Cost Them Big
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: 75% of Australians are worried about potential hikes in their home insurance premiums over the next year. Over half of the respondents have already witnessed a rise in their premiums, attributed to the increasingly erratic climate patterns across Australia. The average Australian's annual home and contents premium has jumped from $2452 to $2795 in the last year.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa shows why everyday Caribbean workers need financial protection
articles.author: Chalsey Gill
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa damaged roads and power lines and disrupted the way people earn a living in the Caribbean. After the storm, farmers can't replant, vendors can't sell, fishers can't go out to sea and tourism workers lose shifts. Many organizations serving vulnerable people had no disaster budget, and 80% weren't collecting regular member fees. CPDC argues for meso-level CDRFI to deliver money faster.

articles.title: Gia Lai Province races to prepare for typhoon Kalmaegi
articles.author: SGGPO
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi is moving toward Central Vietnam. Gia Lai Provincial People's Committee has issued an urgent directive calling on all sectors and localities to proactively implement response measures. The Quy Nhon Port Authority has been instructed to prepare search and rescue resources to ensure the safety of cargo and transport ships in port waters. On land, local authorities are ordered to complete the evacuation of residents from low-lying areas, riverbanks and landslide-prone zones before November 4. More than 1,000 soldiers and officers, equipped with 48 vehicles, six armored carriers, 27 boats and various specialized machines, have been placed on standby to mobilize immediately. Offshore, the Gia

articles.title: 300,000 raptors take to the skies in 'superhighways' where Europe meets Africa. Here's what's going on
articles.author: Sophie.Ellis Ourmedia.Co.Uk
articles.summary: There are three main flyways, or superhighways in the sky, around the globe. Birds move between North and South America along the Americas flyway, the East Asia and Australasia flyway stretches from Alaska to Russia's Taimyr Peninsula in the north and to Australia and New Zealand in the south. The African-Eurasian flyway is the route of choice between Africa and Europe or West Asia. The Strait of Gibraltar is the favoured crossing point between European and African landmasses. Between August and October, observers along the strait regularly record the migrations of 300,000 raptors and 150,000 white and black storks.

articles.title: IMD Issues Cyclone Alert for Andaman and Nicobar
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The India Meteorological Department has issued a cyclone alert for the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. A cyclonic circulation over the Bay of Bengal is predicted to intensify by November 4. There will be squally weather and winds reaching 55 kmph over the North Andaman Sea. Fishermen and tourists are advised not to go into the sea.

articles.title: Indonesia Among Top 10 Countries with Largest Global Forest Gain  Pusat Data Ekonomi dan Bisnis Indonesia
articles.author: databoks.katadata.co.id
articles.summary: Indonesia is among the countries with the largest net gain in forest area globally. China ranks first with an average net gain of 1.69 million hectares per year during 2015-2025. Russia is second, India third, Turkey fourth, Australia fifth, France sixth, South Africa seventh and Vietnam eighth.

articles.title: Philippines evacuates thousands ahead of Typhoon Kalmaegi's landfall
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi is moving toward Leyte Island with sustained winds of around 120 km/h and gusts reaching up to 150km/h. Evacuation operations are underway in several areas, including Palo and Tanauan, which were heavily devastated by super Typhoon Haiyan in 2013. In Dinagat Islands province, around 10,000-15,000 people have been moved to safer locations over the past two days. The Philippine Coast Guard in Western Visayas has been placed on its highest alert level.

articles.title: Sahara Desert Could Get 75% More Rain by 2100, Study Predicts
articles.author: Srishti MS
articles.summary: The study used 40 advanced climate models to simulate rainfall patterns across Africa. The results suggest widespread increases in precipitation in North, East, and Central Africa, but some regions may experience drying instead. Increased rainfall could support vegetation growth and water resources in some areas, but may also bring new flooding and land management challenges.

articles.title: In Switzerland, The Alps Are Melting Amid Climate Change, but Villagers Won't Be Moved
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Blatten in Switzerland was crushed by a glacier. It's a sign of the economic and emotional costs of a warming Europe, as well as the need to rebuild Blatten, which was destroyed by the glacier, and Switzerland is trying to rebuild it now.

articles.title: Analysis: 95% chance global temperatures surpass 2 degrees
articles.author: Sara Schonhardt
articles.summary: The world is almost certain to surpass the 2 degree warming limit set out in the Paris Agreement, according to a new analysis. Global greenhouse gas emissions are likely to stay constant or decline through 2060 before gradually increasing once again. The probability of limiting warming below 2°C before the end of the century remains below 5%.

articles.title: Oshawa's Nov. 3 forecast: Chance of showers
articles.author: Torstar Open Data Team
articles.summary: This story was automatically generated using data from Environment and Climate Change Canada and has been automatically shared via Twitter, Facebook and other social media channels.    .      i   in this case, the article link has been copied and saved.

articles.title: Climate change denial can't stand up to Category 5 Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Climate change denial can't stand up to Category 5 Hurricane Melissa, writes Detroit Free Press' columnist. 'Melissa' is a Category 5 hurricane with winds of up to 100 miles per hour and is headed for Detroit. 'There is no such thing as climate change denial.'

articles.title: Do you live in one of Horry County's most expensive ZIP codes? Where they're at
articles.author: Terri Richardson
articles.summary: There are 21 ZIP codes in Horry County. The wealthiest ZIP code is along U.S. 17 near Briarcliffe Acres within the Myrtle Beach city limits. The largest growing area is located in the Carolina Forest area, with more than 49,000 people living there. The population in Aynor is a little more than 6,000.

articles.title: The World Needs a Climate Adaptation Breakthrough at COP30
articles.author: Ban Ki-Moon
articles.summary: COP30 in Belém, Brazil, is being called the world's first adaptation COP. It's a moment for leadership. Without adaptation, climate change becomes a multiplier of poverty. Developing countries want international adaptation finance to triple by 2030. Today, less than 15% of every climate dollar goes to adaptation.

articles.title: NRMA Insurance, Surfing Australia Expand Partnership
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Since 2020, Australia has experienced 14 declared catastrophes and eight significant weather events. Insurance industry has paid $22.5 billion in insured costs for extreme weather events over the past five years. NSF NCAR provides the atmospheric and related Earth system science community with state-of-the-art resources.

articles.title: South Africa: Informed Citizens Say Climate Change Is Worsening Life in South Africa, Call for Action
articles.author: Asafika Mpako
articles.summary: At least 103 people died in floods in the Eastern Cape province of South Africa, including 32 school-aged children, during the second week of June. In the same week, severe storms destroyed more than 140 homes in the rural community of Impendle and damaged 138 schools in 12 districts in KwaZulu-Natal province. South Africans report taking steps to adapt to changing weather patterns, including changes in water use, outdoor work habits, and livestock management.

articles.title: Jamaican farms reel from Hurricane Melissa, fueling fears of food shortages
articles.summary: Osbourne Brumley's egg farm in Jamaica's St. Elizabeth parish was destroyed by Hurricane Melissa. At least 28 people died because of the storm. Agriculture Minister Floyd Green said Melissa will have a 'crippling effect on our agricultural sector' because some of the hardest-hit parishes are also the most productive.

articles.title: The world expects more than talk at COP30
articles.summary: COP30 convenes in Belém, Brazil on November 10-21, 2025. The world looks to this summit for concrete commitments, real shifts, and accountability. Brazil's hosting of the summit in the Amazon region is symbolically potent as the world's largest tropical forest is under threat. This is not just about reducing emissions but preserving critical planetary systems and ensuring the resilience of vulnerable peoples and ecosystems.

articles.title: How the Greenhouse Effect Really Works (And Why It Matters)
articles.author: Glanze Patrick
articles.summary: The Greenhouse Effect is the process of trapping heat in the atmosphere and releasing it into the Earth's atmosphere. Greenhouse gases that contribute to this process include carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and water vapor. It's essential to understand the greenhouse effect to prevent climate change. Reducing carbon emissions is one of the most direct ways to slow global warming.

articles.title: Native Alaska villages were already on the front lines of climate change. Then a typhoon hit.
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Native Alaska villages were already on the front lines of climate change. Then a typhoon hit them. The typhoon was caused by a climate change-causing extreme weather event, according to Grist.org's report.    i.e. a tropical storm.

articles.title: Climate finance crisis: Poor nations paying for world's inaction
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: The world is spending less on climate adaptation than it needs to spend the most. Developed nations are financing their own adaptation costs from domestic budgets. Developing nations alone require up to USD 387 billion annually this decade. Without large-scale global support, climate impacts could shave off 2 to 3 per cent of India's GDP every year by mid-century.

articles.title: Brown-affiliated studies help explain overestimations in impact of Greenland Ice Sheet melting
articles.author: The Brown Daily Herald
articles.summary: Greenland Ice Sheet is melting at its fastest rate in 12,000 years due to rising surface temperatures caused by man-made climate change. The resulting meltwater is one of the greatest contributors to global sea level rise and threatens to erode the Greenland Ice Sheet.

articles.title: Lake Van water level drops, revealing century-old pier in Türkiye
articles.author: Daily Sabah With Aa
articles.summary: Lake Van, located in eastern Türkiye, is the country's largest soda lake and a critical natural resource for surrounding communities. Severe drought and increased evaporation due to shifting weather patterns have accelerated the retreat of its shoreline. The water receded 500 meters from the historical shoreline, revealing structures that have remained submerged for decades. The exposed wooden pier, believed to be over 100 years old, was once a vital transportation point for local residents.

articles.title: ADB launches 'Glaciers to Farms' program to protect Pakistan's water, agriculture
articles.summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has unveiled a comprehensive plan to help Pakistan safeguard its vital water resources, agricultural productivity, and energy systems in the face of growing climate change challenges. The initiative is titled 'Glaciers to Farms Program' and aims to assess and mitigate the economic and environmental impacts of glacier melt across the country.

articles.title: Manipur: Thousands of migratory Amur falcons arrive in Tamenglong, officials report
articles.author: Bit Irom
articles.summary: The arrival and roosting of Amur falcons in Manipur's Tamenglong district has increased in large numbers in the past 48 hours. The Amur Falcon is one of the world's longest-traveling migratory birds. They start their annual 20,000-kilometer journey from Siberia, China, and Russia to the southern hemisphere and are likely to leave Manipur for South Africa from November 25.

articles.title: So long for now – where do Latvia's birds go for the winter?
articles.author: Vides fakti
articles.summary: Ornithologists point out that birds have different migration strategies and the routes they take to get to their wintering grounds differ. The osprey migrates across the Mediterranean Sea and winters mainly in western Africa. The white stork's wintering area extends all the way to southern Africa, while the black stork stays between the Sahara and the equator. Bird migration is directly affected by climate change. Some bird species are hunted for food, entertainment or feathers.

articles.title: COP30 summit kicks off in Brazil, as business leaders push for clean energy
articles.summary: Countries may be hard-pressed to project the optimism that has marked climate diplomacy in recent years amid geopolitical tension. Climate change could cost Australia more than $8 billion every year by the end of the century, according to Eraldo Peres' estimate.

articles.title: Climate Change Won't End Humanity! Experts Warn Real Doomsday Is Closer Than We Think
articles.author: Shweta Kumari
articles.summary: Billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates has declared that climate change won't lead to humanity's demise. However, experts warn that mankind is creating tools that could erase its existence. They warn of the rise of man-made bioweapons, unregulated AI models and nuclear war.

articles.title: On Track to Cross 1.5°C Before 2030: Global Warming Is Changing How It Rains in India; Know What's Happening
articles.author: Ananya Ganotra
articles.summary: The world is on a dangerous path to surpass the critical 1.5°C global warming threshold before 2030. There is a 47% likelihood that the global temperature averaged over the entire five-year period 2024-2028 will exceed the pre-industrial era limit. The current emission rates risk exhausting the 'carbon budget' within a few years. India witnessed unusual monsoon behaviour in 2025 that signals a climate in flux. The richest 10% have caused two-thirds of global warming since 1990.

articles.title: ‘Future Shock' meets MAGA culture shock
articles.summary: Trump's climate warming denialism could mean the end of human life as Toffler knew it. Jim Cain is a Wakefield resident. He believes in science and logic, not in a mind that is immune to facts. He is against Trump's climate change denialism.

articles.title: Mosquitoes in Iceland and more: how climate change is making people sick
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: The Lancet Countdown Report is authored by 128 leading scientists. According to the report, the health consequences of climate change have never been more dangerous for human health. Last year was the warmest on record, with atmospheric CO2 levels reaching new highs. The average person experienced a record 16 extra days of high temperatures.

articles.title: Rising heat worsens chronic illnesses in rural Zimbabwe
articles.author: Staff reporter
articles.summary: As climate change drives temperatures higher across Zimbabwe, people living with chronic illnesses in rural areas are facing a devastating crisis. Rural residents can escape the heat in clinics, air-conditioned buildings, or homes with fans, but villagers in remote areas like Nyamandlovu remain exposed to the full brunt of rising temperatures. Without proper infrastructure or medical support, the excessive heat is quietly worsening the health of those already vulnerable.

articles.title: Alarmingly Low Sunscreen Use: Only 33% of Australians Adhere to Daily Sun Protection Guidelines
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Just over one-third of Australians apply sunscreen most days, whereas more than half spend over 15 minutes outdoors during peak UV hours. Nearly seven per cent of Australians have suffered sunburns. The Australian Capital Territory had the best sun-safe behaviour, followed by the ACT, Greater Darwin and Greater Brisbane.

articles.title: Marina Shacola exhibition captures Turkana people in Kenya's desert
articles.author: newsroom
articles.summary: Omicron Gallery presents Sunscapes, a new photography exhibition by Marina Shacola, running from 8 to 28 November 2025 in Nicosia. The Sunscape series documents the people of the Turkana desert in northern Kenya within the harsh, unforgiving landscape that surrounds them. Livestock farming has been the main source of survival for generations in the area, but the discovery of oil in 2012 has brought new economic and political interests.

articles.title: The next RBA rate move is more likely to be up than down
articles.author: Paul Bloxham
articles.summary: An unexpectedly hot inflation report has changed the game for the Reserve Bank of Australia. When there is a big surprise like this, there are typically two responses from the market, writes HSBC's Paul Bloxham, and the market usually reacts with one of them.

articles.title: The next RBA rate move is likely to be up than down
articles.author: Paul Bloxham
articles.summary: An unexpectedly hot inflation report has changed the game for the Reserve Bank of Australia. When there is a big surprise like this, there are typically two responses from the market, writes HSBC's Paul Bloxham, and the market usually reacts with one of them.

articles.title: Top 10 US billionaires' collective wealth grew by $698bn in past year
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Oxfam warns Trump's policies risk driving inequality to new heights. Democrats have also exacerbated the wealth gap, according to Oxfam's research. The research was based on data from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and Oxfam.org.

articles.title: Only third of Aussies are wearing sunscreen most days, in line with guidelines
articles.author: 9News
articles.summary: Just over a third of Aussies are wearing sunscreen most days. More than half of us spend more than 15 minutes outside in peak UV hours. Cancer Council recommends using sunscreen every day on days when the UV Index is forecast to be 3 or above. Almost 7 per cent of Australians have experienced a sunburn.

articles.title: Red-listed lesser redpoll spotted near Herefordshire village
articles.author: Julia Baker
articles.summary: A red-listed bird has been spotted near a rural Herefordshire village. Two lesser redpolls were spotted at Gamber Meadows near St. Weonards. The species is on the UK Conservation List. There are estimated 220,000 breeding pairs across the UK.

articles.title: Farmers Voice Key Facts on Net Zero Climate Targets
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Farmers for Climate Action points out the cost of climate change to farmers. 90% of the world's pollution comes from fossil fuels. Extreme heat days in Australia have increased tenfold since the 1960s. Farmers are on track to make $1 billion in drought-proof payments from clean energy companies by 2030. There is no nuclear without net zero commitments.

articles.title: Powerful earthquake kills nine at least in northern Afghanistan
articles.author: Sharjah 24
articles.summary: Residents of Mazar-I-Sharif rushed into the streets as buildings shook during the late-night earthquake. The disaster marks the latest in a series of powerful earthquakes to strike Afghanistan in recent years. Since the Taliban took control in 2021, the country has endured three major quakes stretching already limited resources and international aid.

articles.title: Eau Claire man wants to help family and community back home in Jamaica after devastation from Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Daniel Gomez
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica less than a week ago. At least 28 people died on the island. Christopher Heath lives in Wisconsin. He and his wife LaReah are trying to send barrels of food, clothing and other supplies to Jamaica. They have a GoFundMe to help them.

articles.title: Westerman: Beef trade policy should ‘change course'
articles.author: James Bright
articles.summary: U.S. Rep. Bruce Westerman met with local cattle ranchers to hear their concerns and provide insight on his work to bring them some relief. The agricultural business continues to face challenges in the current climate and Westerman wants to help them out.

articles.title: Scorched Future
articles.author: Statesman News Service
articles.summary: Last year's heatwave in India would not have occurred without the warming effect of human activity. An estimated 247 billion potential labour hours were lost, mainly among those whose livelihoods depend on working outdoors. Fossil fuel emissions, along with the burning of wood and crop residue, continue to choke cities and villages. In 2022, over 1.7 million deaths were attributed to air pollution in India.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Unleashes Severe Weather Impact on Southeast Asia: A Comprehensive Overview of Effects and Responses
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: Karding has brought severe weather conditions to several countries across Southeast Asia, particularly the Philippines, Vietnam, and parts of Thailand. The northern and central regions of the Philippines have borne the brunt of the storm. The most pressing concern is the humanitarian crisis unfolding across affected regions. Over 500,000 people have been displaced in the Philippines alone. The storm has inflicted significant damage on critical infrastructure, leading to substantial economic losses. Several countries have pledged emergency relief supplies.

articles.title: Afghanistan: At least 7 killed, over 150 injured in 6.3-magnitude quake; Mazar-i-Sharif shrine partly destroyed
articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.summary: At least seven people were killed and 150 injured after an earthquake of magnitude 6.3 struck Afghanistan on Sunday. The earthquake hit at a depth of 28 km near Mazar-e Sharif, which has a population of 523,000. The USGS issued an orange alert in its PAGER system, which indicated "significant casualties are likely and the disaster is potentially widespread".

articles.title: Antarctica in a Potential Ice-Free Future: A Climate Change Scenario Antarctica Unveiled: Visualizing a Future without Ice Antarctica Without Ice: Imagining a Dramatic Climate Change Outcome
articles.summary: Antarctica in a Potential Ice-Free Future: A Climate Change Scenario explores the potential consequences of significant Antarctic ice melt, sea-level rise, climate impacts, and geopolitical shifts. The Antarctic ice sheet holds approximately 61% of all the freshwater on Earth. Even partial melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could raise global sea levels by several meters.

articles.title: COP30 SUMMIT IN BRAZIL: Bangladesh to present 'Just Transition' agenda
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Bangladesh will introduce the concept of a 'Just Transition', a framework that integrates climate-affected communities into decent employment, at the upcoming COP30 summit in Belém, Brazil, on November 10-21. The Just Transition framework ensures that workers and communities affected by the shift to a low-carbon economy are not left behind. The environment ministry is working with development partners to identify priority sectors for the transition.

articles.title: Experts issue warning about ongoing impacts after powerful storm strikes US: 'Every inch matters'
articles.author: Michael Muir
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong hit Alaska's southwest coast on October 11 with hurricane force. Over 1,000 people have been displaced and at least one person has been killed. Indigenous Alaskan villages of Kwigillingok and Kipnuk were hit hardest. The combination of permafrost loss and rising sea levels is making the communities acutely vulnerable. At least 10 villages will have to be relocated. The most at-risk villages are those that sit atop the diminishing Permafrost. The Environmental Protection Agency revoked a $20 million grant to improve its defenses against further erosion in May 2025.

articles.title: The climate bill comes due
articles.author: Editorial Board
articles.summary: Farmers from Sindh are taking RWE and Heidelberg to court for damages caused by Pakistan's devastating 2022 floods. They lost two harvests and watched their land stay under water for over a year. The 2022 floods submerged a third of the country, killed over 1,700 people, displaced 33 million and caused losses of up to $30 billion. Pakistan contributes less than one per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions but is on the frontlines of the climate crisis.

articles.title: Israel's enablers
articles.author: Chris Hedges
articles.summary: Gaza does not mark the end of the settler colonial project. Western states, enriched by their own occupations and genocides, are returning to their roots as they face a global climate crisis and obscene levels of social inequality that they engineer and sustain. Global average concentration of CO2 surged by 3.5 parts per million, from June 2023 to June 2024. The United States has given $21.7 billion in military aid to Israel since October 7, 2023.

articles.title: Greenwood Great House severely damaged by Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: The Greenwood Great House in St James was destroyed by Hurricane Melissa. The 225-year-old structure lost its roof and other key parts of the infrastructure. The landmark structure served the Barrett family of which renowned poet Elizabeth Barrett-Browning is connected to. It served as a museum up to the passage of the storm.

articles.title: Carbon markets are the backbone of a low-carbon future - but only if governments seize this opportunity
articles.author: Peter Bakker
articles.summary: Climate change is resulting in increased costs for businesses. The financial impacts are already evident and anticipated to be felt. The effects of extreme weather events and heightened supply chain risks are already visible and are expected to have a financial impact on businesses. It is also predicted to increase the risk of supply chain disruptions.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor, Nov. 3, 2025
articles.author: Postmedia News
articles.summary: Bill Gates' new perspective on climate change should be taken seriously: Government policy must transition from moral posturing to human welfare. Canada needs to move beyond symbolic carbon targets toward innovation that lowers costs and strengthens global competitiveness. Doug Ford's letter to the editor in the Wall Street Journal was wisely chosen.

articles.title: An invitation to fall in love with Thai cooking
articles.author: Nat Thaipun
articles.summary: 3. Preheat the barbecue or grill to medium-high. If using a charcoal barbecue, wait until the coals are ashed over for even cooking. Cook the chicken for about 20 to 30 minutes on each side, turning occasionally, until the skin is crispy, golden and the internal temperature reaches 75°.

articles.title: Bob Marshall: State's longterm plan to save the coast is getting short shrift
articles.author: BOB MARSHALL
articles.summary: Louisiana's Coastal Protection and Restoration Authority introduced the 50-year, $50 billion Master Plan for a Sustainable Coast in 2007. Governor Jeff Landry killed the first two river sediment diversions in the master plan. He's an oil man turned politician and a noted climate change skeptic. He thinks Louisiana's future is in more oil and gas production. He didn't announce any plans for the future.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa deals heavy blow to Jamaica's farmers
articles.author: The Pioneer
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is blamed for at least 19 deaths in Jamaica, bringing catastrophic winds up to 298 kph and storm surge that wrecked homes and public infrastructure. It's already clear that the storm dealt a devastating blow to Jamaican fishers and farmers who feed their families and nearby communities. Similar impacts will be felt in Cuba and Haiti.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: Seychelles expresses solidarity with Jamaica and the Caribbean Islands affected by hurricane Melissa. Dr Patrick Herminie, President of the Republic of Seychelles extends his profound sympathy and unwavering solidarity to Jamaica and all Caribbean nations affected by the hurricane.

articles.title: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by almost half in just two months. Scientists say it could ...
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier shrunk by nearly 50% in just two months. It's the fastest retreat recorded in modern history. The way it retreated could have implications for global sea level rise. The glacier is roughly the size of Philadelphia. It is on the Antarctic Peninsula.

articles.title: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by almost half in just two months. Scientists say it could happen again
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by nearly 50 per cent in just two months, according to the Antarctic Institute for Research on Ice and Science.    The glacier is located in the Antarctic Peninsula, south of the Larsen Archipelago, Antarctica. The glacier has shrunk by almost half in two months.

articles.title: Why global warming could be ‘rewriting race history' at major marathon events
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Study claims that rising temperatures will make it harder for elite athletes to break the marathon world record or for heat exhaustion during races as a result of dehydration and heat exhaustion in the future. The study was based on data from the Global Warming Policy Foundation.

articles.title: 13 years after Sandy, NJ can't gamble on climate change. Sherrill for governor
articles.author: New Jersey Herald
articles.summary: On the thirteenth anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, climate inaction is driving up utility costs and putting New Jersey in a worse position than in 2012. Sandy damaged or destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes and took 38 lives.    New Jersey was hit hard by Hurricane Sandy.

articles.title: A decade of the Paris Agreement brings progress and setbacks (Lunds universitet)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Fariborz Zelli sums up the surprises in climate policy over the past ten years and looks ahead to the future. The countries of the world signed the Paris Agreement ten years ago and it has been a positive and negative thing for both the world and for the climate.

articles.title: Chaos on Cambodia's Coast
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Illegal trawling, elite-backed development and weak enforcement are driving Cambodia's marine ecosystems and fishing communities to the brink. This is happening along Cambodia's rapidly transforming coastline. It is driving marine ecosystems to the verge of extinction. This 2024.

articles.title: This Antarctic Glacier Just Broke An Unwanted Record – Fastest Retreat In Modern History
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: The Hektoria Glacier is disappearing at a fast rate, losing almost half of its area. This is 10 times faster than any glacier ever observed. The glacier has little impact on sea levels, but the processes that made it possible could happen on larger glaciers, so it's a warning.

articles.title: Italian winemakers look to new technologies with old grape varieties to adapt to a changing climate
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Italy's vineyards are struggling with erratic weather and dwindling water due to longer and hotter summers and longer summers in Italy's vineyard, and longer, hotter summers in the past few years. The vineyard industry is struggling with dwindling water supplies in Italy, as well.

articles.title: The ground is swallowing homes in this Native village in Alaska. Residents have no choice ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The climate crisis is causing the permafrost to melt in Alaska, forcing the village of Nunapitchuk to relocate because of the melting permafrosts. The village will have to move. The population has to be relocated because of climate change.

articles.title: Scientists warn glacier vanished faster than any other in modern history
articles.author: Watauga Democrat
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier on Antarctica's Eastern Peninsula retreated at an unprecedented rate in 2023.       .   "Unprecedented" retreated at "unprecedented rate" in  2023, according to the scientists.  "Hektoria Glacier retreated at unprecedented rate".

articles.title: North India's winter guestlist: The epic journey of the migratory birds
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Birds are migrating to North India in search of a warmer climate for food and breeding purposes in wintertime. They are comparing it with the warmer climate of India. It's not just a human thing, it's also a bird thing as well. It is a sign of winter.

articles.title: Bob Marshall: State's longterm plan to save the coast is getting short shrift
articles.author: The Advocate
articles.summary: Twenty years ago, Louisiana began two campaigns essential to hopes for the long-term habitability of the coastal zone. It is the most populous and economically important region in the state. It's hoped it will be habitable in the long term. It will be habitable in the near future.

articles.title: In Switzerland, the Alps are melting, but the villagers will not be moved
articles.summary: Researchers have long warned of the dangers that climate change poses to people and property in mountainous areas like the Alps. The main cause of climate change is the burning of fossil fuels, which is mainly caused by the combustion of fossil fuel.   Â
